description: Application for Variation of Condition 2 (Approved Plans) and Condition 3 (External Materials) of Planning Permission ref: 18/14306/FUL (Erection of 2 x 3 storey 4 bedroom semi-detached dwellings) dated 08/08/2018 to include internal alterations and changes to external materials and fenestration
decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Refuse storage facilities and recycling facilities shall be provided prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted in accordance with details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to above ground works. Such facilities shall be permanently retained at the site.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development above ground level shall commence until a landscaping scheme including front boundary treatment and where applicable the retention of the existing trees shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.  Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.  Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012. These details are required prior to commencement of development to ensure the development would have a satisfactory appearance.

Notwithstanding the provisions of Part 1 of Schedule 2 of the Town and Country (General Permitted Development) Order (England) 2015, no extensions (including porches or dormer windows) to the dwelling houses or buildings shall be erected within the curtilage.Reason: To safeguard the privacy and amenity of adjoining occupiers, maintain adequate amenity space and safeguard the cohesive appearance of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

By the time the development hereby permitted is substantially complete, pedestrian/vehicular intervisibility splays of 2.8m x 3.3m shall have been provided in each direction where the access meets the back edge of footway, and shall be permanently retained free from any obstruction to visibility higher than 1.0m above ground level.Reason: To maintain pedestrian/vehicular intervisibility in the interest of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, any windows or rooflights in the east and west facing side elevations and situated on the first floor and above and also the side window panels in the first floor front bay windows shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable.  Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

All works on site shall take place in accordance with the following details which shall have previously been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the commencement of work:(a)	Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b)	Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(c)	Means of enclosure of the site/hoarding.(d)	Wheel washing equipment.(e)	The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitorsReason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase an in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of original permission 18/14306/FUL (08/08/2018).Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The car parking accommodation shown upon the approved drawings shall be provided with a permeable, hard bound dust free surface, adequately drained before the development to which it relates is occupied and thereafter it shall be kept free from obstruction at all times for use by the occupier of the development and shall not thereafter be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion of surrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No part of the development hereby approved shall be occupied until evidence has been submitted to the council confirming that the development has achieved not less than the CO2 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes level 4. Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from Ene1 & Wat1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Technical Guide. Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105l/p/ day must be submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall not be occupied until details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, the development hereby approved have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
E4 - Acoustic Conditions in Schools

Condition 10 (CO2 Emissions Reductions and Internal Water Useage) -  Officers have reviewed the infomation submitted and are satisfied that it has been demonstrated that a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations in relation to CO2 reductions and an internal water usage rate of 105 l/p/day has been achieved and this condition can now be approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 10 (CO2 Emissions Reductions and Internal Water Useage) of Planning Permission ref: 16/14822/FUL is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.
You are reminded of the need to obtain separate consent under the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) for any proposed alterations to the shopfront.

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling located to the south of The Mount, New Malden.The existing building is not locally or statutorily listed and is not within a Conservation Area.ProposalErection of single storey side and rear extensionConsultations 6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposal and no representations were received.Planning History21/02745/CEU - Erection of a rear dormer roof extension, installation of two windows and 1no. rear rooflight  to facilitate loft conversion. Granted 20.10.2021.21/01407/HOU - Erection of single storey rear/side extension and rear dormer roof extension - Refused 23.08.2021Reasons for Refusal:1.	The proposed rear dormer roof extension would be of an excessive size and would represent poor design that would be contrary to Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021, Policies CS8 (Character, Design and Heritage) and DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments (including House Extensions)) of the Core Strategy (April 2012) and Policy Guidance 39 (Dormer Windows) of the Council's Residential Design SPD (2013).AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The previous application (21/01407/HOU) was refused on the basis that the rear dormer roof extension was considered to be unacceptable in terms of design, scale, form and bulk. A lawful development certificate (21/02745/CEU) has since been approved for the rear dormer which is shown on the plans.No concerns were raised in relation to the side and rear extension. The depth of the rear extension has increased from 4m to 4.3m through this proposal but the height remains the same. The proposed side extension does not fully comply with the guidance set out in Policy 35 of the Residential Design SPD (in terms of width and set back from the front elevation) but this is considered acceptable on the basis of the existing situation/garage and as it will not give a different appearance from the street. The extension steps up in height as extends to the rear but this is sufficiently set back. Overall, the proposed side and rear extension is considered subordinate in scale to the main dwelling, appropriate in design and is not unreasonable in height (flat roof of 3.3m), broadly matching the height of neighbouring extensions. For these reasons, the proposal would not have an adverse impacts on the character and appearance of the area and is considered in accordance with Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021, Policies CS8 (Character, Design and Heritage) and DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments (including House Extensions)) of the Core Strategy (April 2012) and Policy Guidance 33 and 35 of the Council's Residential Design SPD (2013).Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  No concerns were raised through the previous application in relation to the side and rear extension. With regard to No. 9 The Mount, this property has an existing extension and the proposed rear extension extends only marginally beyond this and so the proposal is not considered to result in an undue impact on the amenity of this neighbour in terms of visual intrusion, loss of daylight, sunlight or privacy.With regard to No. 5 The Mount, the proposed extension extends to the neighbour boundary and approximately 3.4m beyond the rear extension of this neighbour. This, combined with the height of the extension (3.65 to the parapet) which is not considered unreasonable, is not considered to result in an undue impact to the amenities of this neighbour in terms of visual intrusion, loss of daylight, sunlight or privacy. The larger rear extension to the neighbouring dwelling has a window directly facing the proposed extension but this is a secondary window and no concerns are raised in terms of amenity.In summary, the proposal is considered in accordance with Policy DM 10 of the Core Strategy (2012).ConclusionOverall, the proposed side and rear extension is considered acceptable by reason of its design, siting, scale, height and depth and  would not have an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the area, existing building or the amenities of neighbours. The proposal is therefore in accordance with Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021, Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and Policy Guidance 33 and 35 of the Council's Residential Design SPD (2013).

SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwellinghouse located on Alexandra Drive. The site is partly located within Flood Zone 2. ConsultationsFour neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on drainage. The impact of the development on highways. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officers Comments: The site is located within Flood Zone 2, which has a medium probability of flooding. The submitted flood risk form states that floor levels within the proposed development will be set no lower than existing levels and flood proofing of the proposed development has been incorporated where appropriate which is considered acceptable in this case and in compliance with policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy DM10 supports this stance. Officers Comments: The proposal involves the removal of an existing garage. Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate at least one off-street car parking spaces. The proposed parking provision retained would therefore be unlikely to contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that the Planning Condition 11 (Drainage) of planning permission 20/03274/FUL is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The submitted CMP is unclear about proposed parking arrangements for staff/contractors. The applicant is advised that no construction-related vehicle is permitted to park on any residential road in the vicinity of the site regardless of any general parking restrictions that may or may not be in place, with the exception of pay and display bays where parking is permitted in accordance with standard regulations.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details for Condition 3 (Facing Materials Samples) of planning permission 19/02482/FUL have been assessed and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details.
Condition 23 (Piling) - Thames Water and RBK Officers have reviewed the information submitted and are satisfied this can now be approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 23 (Piling Method Statement) of Planning Permission 20/02219/CREG3 is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.
